Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Transitions To A Nomadic Lifestyle

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
PhD Candidate Brandi Bethke, of the University of Arizona, will examine the extent to which the adoption of the horse altered landscape uses, bison hunting practices, and worldviews of the Blackfoot during the protohistoric and historic periods in the northwestern Plains of the U.S. and Canada. Inspired by the richness of hunter-gatherer archaeology in the northern Plains, theoretical and methodological advances in geospatial mapping, and Blackfoot traditional knowledge, this work provides new insights into the region's equestrian culture and society. Employing a framework that integrates archaeology, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), social history, and ethnography, Bethke's research will provide a contemporary model and nuanced narrative of the influence of the horse on Blackfoot lifeways. Specifically this research will answer the question: to what extent (if any) did the Blackfoot become true nomadic pastoralists? Overall Bethke's work provides an opportunity to evaluate and update the history of the horse and its incorporation into social, economic, and political systems of nomadic hunters on the northern Plains, a story that is integral to the United States' shared heritage and history of western expansion. More broadly, this work will promote an archaeological practice that is not only scientifically sound but also responsive to the traditional knowledge and practices of Blackfoot tribal members. Present-day Blackfoot peoples offer unique perspectives and hold significant knowledge regarding cultural change associated with the introduction of the horse among their ancestors. This collaboration and constructive dialogue between archaeologists and Blackfeet non-archaeologists will benefit the discipline of archaeology in that it will provide new modes of analysis for interpreting relationships between humans and their domesticated animals both in the past and present.

Bethke's work will refine and expand models developed in earlier works in order to evaluate how the transition from a bison-centered to a horse-centered lifestyle altered land use patterns as the Blackfoot began to follow habits of horses instead of bison for their own annual cycles of subsistence activities, integrative ceremonies, labor organization, economy, and trade. Additionally, while the socio-economic consequences of the horse have been studied from a historical perspective, the archaeology of this transition remains ambiguous. This study will integrate locational information of multiple archaeological site types from Montana, Alberta, and Saskatchewan with historic and ethnographic data, in order to produce a comprehensive GIS database that will then be used to analyze shifts in land use patterns over the whole of Blackfoot territory that is not limited by modern geopolitical borders. In this way Bethke's research presents a new, archaeological dimension to the dynamics of the Blackfoot equestrian transition by incorporating material culture with traditional knowledge, historic accounts, and scientific data into a multi-scalar, transnational interpretation within the framework of world pastoralist studies. Pastoralism as a mode of production has never before been formally considered as a way of life experienced by Native North Americas. This project will therefore contribute new theoretical and methodological approaches as well as substantive data to our understanding of hunting and pastoralism among people of the North American Plains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of the National Science Foundation, this dissertation research evaluates and updates the history of the horse and its incorporation into the social, economic, political, religious, and land-use systems of nomadic hunters on the Northwestern Plains. This work unites a diverse set of methodological components and data into a study of cultural change that expands on previous work while at the same time contributing a new, material dimension on the dynamics of this equestrian transition. The results of this research conclude that the horse had a significant, lasting impact on the Blackfoot people that developed into a new nomadic pastoralist horse culture during the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, was adapted to a settled farmer-rancher lifestyle in the twentieth century, and continues to evolve today.

The Blackfoot pastoralist trajectory represents a strong case study for exploring the relationship between pastoralism and hunting communities. Results from this research contribute new theory, methods, and data for a better understanding of the dynamic relationship between hunting and pastoralism among ancient societies, a topic that has traditionally been underrepresented in North American archaeological literature. This work supports the findings of current world pastoralist research that suggest abundant variability exists between pastoralist economies in terms of their modes of production, herd management strategies, social organization, land tenure, and interactions with outside groups. While the Blackfoot were not eating their horses, they came to consider the horse indispensable for obtaining bison, their main food source. This system differs from classic pastoralist models in that the loss of horse herds does not represent a direct loss of subsistence, but rather an indirect loss over their ability to procure food and other resources. Although pedestrian bison hunting methods were still practiced following the introduction of the horse, hunting without horses represented a significant loss in power within the Blackfoot worldview and consequently the ability to encounter and overtake bison. In this way, the adoption of the horse revolutionized Blackfoot culture, despite the fact that Blackfoot remained bison hunters. Although this work focused exclusively on the Blackfoot case study, a similar process may have occurred among other horse-rich Plains tribes.

In addition to subsistence and social institutions, a key distinction between nomadic pastoralists and nomadic hunter-gatherers is the reasoning behind their mobility strategies. Within this research, archaeological data were successfully incorporated into a GIS database that used spatial statistics to assess changes in settlement patterns between the pre- and post- equestrian periods. The results from this study show a significant shift in the preferred placement of camps nearer to landscape features identified as more favorable for horses (such as abundant water sources) during the Contact period, thus confirming the hypothesis that the historic Blackfoot people changed the way they moved about their landscape in response to the needs of their horses. Ethnohistoric data collected as part of this study also supports these conclusions. By utilizing existing archaeological databases and technical literature housed at state and provincial repositories this work demonstrates the potential for this information in answering questions that require “big data” to expose anthropological patterns. This “grey literature” has traditionally been underutilized within academic research, despite providing substantive, valuable data to the field.

One of the most important outcomes of this work is the realization that, despite being integrally tied to bison hunting, Blackfoot horse culture did not die out with the bison or confinement to reservations and reserves, nor did their use of horses diminish. On the contrary, even in the face of hardship the Blackfoot people are able to adapt their culture to the changing realities of the twenty-first century in order to accommodate the culturally central place of the horse. These profound effects of the horse on Blackfoot culture attest to the fact that the horse was more than just a “new and improved dog” to the Blackfoot. The horse instead initiated a radical shift that transformed their worldviews, social organization, and attachments to the landscape. Today, the Blackfoot peoples of the United States and Canada endure as an evolving hunter-rancher society that places a high value on horses and the freedom they bring to their people. This is an important reminder that archaeology does not have to operate exclusively in the past, but instead may also encompass how historic interactions leave lasting effects on present populations. Modern Blackfoot people make unique contributions toward a better understanding of cultural change associated with the introduction of the horse among their ancestors. This project has benefited immensely through collaboration by offering an alternative framework for looking at the relationship between historic and contemporary Blackfoot peoples and their horses. At the same time, the information produced by this dissertation research will be used by tribal elders and officials for their own cultural initiatives, including future archaeological work, heritage management, and educational programs.
